Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Expectation2: Teach Torah and Jewish law to children and adults.
Situation2: The weekly required religious school class for children is set to occur.
Story: I glance at my phone, seeing the text from Rachel: “Can’t wait for tonight. Just us.” My heart lifts—this is our only evening together before I leave for the conference. She’s been patient with my schedule, and I promised her this night. But as I set the phone down, my email pings. It’s the synagogue board: a reminder that I’m leading the children’s Torah class tonight, as I do every week. There’s no one else to cover; the parents expect me, and the kids look forward to our sessions. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in. Rachel’s face flashes in my mind, hopeful and trusting. Then I picture the circle of children, waiting for stories and guidance. I want to be the boyfriend who keeps his word, who makes her feel cherished. But I’m also the rabbi, responsible for nurturing young souls. My chest tightens as I realize I can’t be in two places at once. The clock ticks, and I sit frozen, torn between love and duty, knowing that whatever I choose, someone will be disappointed.
